encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Theodor Putskie Olimpia Second Woman Petesca Alinda Duke Burris First Woman Archas Barosky Ancient First Soldier Second Soldier Post Second Post First Gentleman Second Gentleman First Woman Second Woman Servant Viola Honora Multiple Third Soldier Fourth Soldier Second Servant Lady Prologue Epilogue

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.speaker: Theodor.
sp.l: Captain, your friend is preferred, the Princess has her,
Who, I assure myself, will use her nobly;
A pretty sweet one it is indeed.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Well bred Sir,
I do deliver that upon my credit,
And of an honest stock.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: It seems so Captain,
And no doubt will do well.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Thanks to your care sir;
But tell me Noble Colonel, why this habit
Of discontent is put on through the Army?
And why your valiant father, our great General,
The hand that taught to strike, the Love that lead all;
Why he, that was the father of the war,
He that begot, and bred the Soldier,
Why he sits shaking of his Arms, like Autumn,
His Colours folded, and his Drums cased up,
The tongue of war forever tied within us?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: It must be so: Captain you are a stranger,
But of a small time here a soldier,
Yet that time shows ye a right good, and great one,
Else I could tell ye hours are strangely altered:
The young Duke has too many eyes upon him,
Too many fears it is thought too, and to nourish those,
Maintains too many Instruments.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Turn their hearts,
Or turn their heels up, heaven: It is strange it should be.
The old Duke loved him dearly.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: He deserved it;
And were he not my Father, I durst tell ye,
The memorable hazards he has run through
Deserved of this man too; highly deserved too;
Had they been less, they had been safe Putskie,
And sooner reached regard.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: There you struck sure sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Did I never tell thee of a vow he made
Some years before the old Duke died?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: I have heard ye
Speak often of that vow; but how it was,
Or to what end, I never understood yet?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I will tell thee then: and then thou wilt find the reason:
The last great Muster, (it was before ye served here,
Before the last Dukes death, whose honoured bones
Now rest in peace) this young Prince had the ordering,
(To Crown his fathers hopes) of all the Army:
Who (to be short) put all his power to practise;
Fashioned, and drew them up: but alas, so poorly
So raggedly and loosely, so unsoldiered,
The good Duke blushed, and called unto my father,
Who then was General: Go Archus speedily,
And chide the Boy, before the soldier find him,
Stand thou between his ignorance and them,
Fashion their bodies new to thy direction:
Then draw thou up, and show the Prince his errors.
My Sire obeyed, and did so; with all duty
Informed the Prince, and read him all directions:
This bred distaste, distaste grew up to anger,
And anger into wild words broke out thus:
Well Archus, if I live but to command here,
To be but Duke once, I shall then remember,
I shall remember truly, trust me, I shall,
And by my Fathers hand; the rest his eyes spoke.
To which my Father answered (somewhat moved too)
And with a vow he sealed it: Royal sir,
Since for my faith and fights, your I corn and anger
Only pursue me; if I live to that day,
That day so long expected to reward me,
By his so ever noble hand you swore by,
And by the hand of Justice, never Arms more
Shall rib this body in, nor sword hang here, sir:
The Conflicts I will do you service then in,
Shall be repentant prayers. So they parted.
The time is come; and now you know the wonder.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: I find a fear too, which begins to tell me,
The Duke will have but poor and slight defences
If his hot humour reign, and not his honour:
How stand you with him, Sir?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: A perdue Captain,
Full of my fathers danger.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: He has raised a young man,
They say a slight young man, I know him not,
For what desert?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Believe it, a brave Gentleman,
Worth the Dukes respect, a clear sweet Gentleman,
And of a noble soul: Come, let us retire us,
And wait upon my father, who within this hour
You will find an altered man.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: I am sorry for it sir.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Is it not a handsome wench?

sp.speaker: 2. Wom.
sp.l: She is well enough Madam:
I have seen a better face, and a straighter body,
And yet she is a pretty Gentle-woman..

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: What thinkst thou Petesca?

sp.speaker: Petes.
sp.l: Alas, Madam, I have no skill, she has a black eye,
Which is of the least too and the dullest water:
And when her mouth was made, for certain Madam,
Nature intended her a right good stomach.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: She has a good hand.

sp.speaker: 2 Wom.
sp.l: It is good enough to hold fast.
And strong enough to strangle the neck of a Lute.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: What think ye of her colour?

sp.speaker: Petes.
sp.l: If it be her own
It is good black blood: right weatherproof
I warrant it.

sp.speaker: 2 Wom.
sp.l: What a strange pace she has got?

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: That is but her breeding.

sp.speaker: Petes.
sp.l: And what a manly body? methinks she looks
As though she would pitch the Bar, or go to Buffets.

sp.speaker: 2 Wom.
sp.l: Yet her behaviour is utterly against it,
For methinks she is too bashful.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Is that hurtful?

sp.speaker: 2 Wo.
sp.l: Even equal to too bold: either of them Madam
May do her injury when time shall serve her.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: You discourse learnedly, call in the wench.
What envious fools are you? Is the rule general,
That women can speak handsomely of none,
But those they are bred withal?

sp.speaker: Petes.
sp.l: Scarce well of those Madam,
If they believe they may out-shine them any way:
Our natures are like oil, compound us with anything,
Yet still we strive to swim on the top:
Suppose there were here now,
Now in this court of Mosco, a stranger Princess,
Of blood and beauty equal to your excellence,
As many eyes and services stuck on her;
What would you think?

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: I would think she might deserve it.

sp.speaker: Petes.
sp.l: Your grace shall give me leave not to believe ye;
I know you are a woman, and so humoured:
I will tell ye Madam, I could then get more gowns on ye,
More caps and feathers, more scarfs, and more silk stockings,
With rocking you asleep with nightly railings
Upon that woman, than if I had nine lives
I could wear out: by this hand ye would scratch her eyes out.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Thou art deceived fool;
Now let your own eyes mock ye.
Come hither girl: hang me if she be not a handsome one.

sp.speaker: Petes.
sp.l: I fear it will prove indeed so.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Did you ever serve yet
In any place of worth?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: No Royal Lady.

sp.speaker: Petes.
sp.l: Hold up your head; fie.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Let her alone, stand from her.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: It shall be now,
Of all the blessings my poor youth has prayed for,
The greatest and the happiest to serve you;
And might my promise carry but that credit
To be believed, because I am yet a stranger,
Excellent Lady, when I fall from duty,
From all the service that my life can lend me,
May ever-lasting misery then find me.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: What think ye now? I do believe, and thank ye;
And sure I shall not be so far forgetful,
To see that honest faith die unrewarded:
What must I call your name?

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Alinda Madam.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Can ye sing?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: A little, when my grief will give me leave, Lady.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: What grief canst thou have wench?
Thou art not in love?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: If I be Madam, it is only with your goodness;
For yet I never saw that man I sighed for.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Of what years are you?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: My mother oft has told me,
That very day and hour this land was blessed
With your most happy birth, I first saluted
This worlds fair light: Nature was then so busy,
And all the Graces to adorn your goodness,
I stole into the world poor and neglected.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Something there was, when I first looked upon thee,
Made me both like and love thee: now I know it;
And you shall find that knowledge shall not hurt you:
I hope ye are a Maid?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I hope so too, Madam;
I am sure for any man: and were I otherwise,
Of all the services my hopes could point at,
I durst not touch at yours.

div2.stage: Flourish. Enter Duke, Burris, and Gent.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: The great Duke, Madam.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Good morrow, sister.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: A good day to your highness.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: I am come to pray you use no more persuasions
For this old stubborn man: nay to command ye:
His sail is swelled too full: he is grown too insolent,
Too self-affected, proud: those poor slight services
He has done my father, and myself, has blown him
To such a pitch, he flies to stoop our favours.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: I am sorry sir: I ever thought those services
Both great and noble.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: However, may it please ye
But to consider them a true hearts servants,
Done out of faith to you, and not self-fame:
But to consider royal sir, the dangers;
When you have slept secure, the mid-night tempests,
That as he marched sung through his aged locks;
When you have fed at full, the wants and famines;
The fires of heaven, when you have found all temperate,
Death with his thousand doors --

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: I have considered;
No more: and that I will have, shall be.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: For the best,
I hope all still.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: What handsome wench is that there?

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: My servant, sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Prithee observe her Burris.
Is she not wondrous handsome? speak thy freedom.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: She appears no less to me sir.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Of whence is she?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Her father I am told is a good gentleman,
But far off dwelling: her desire to serve me
Brought her to the Court, and here her friends have left her.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: She may find better friends:
Ye are welcome fair one,
I have not seen a sweeter: By your Ladies leave:
Nay stand up sweet, we will have no superstition:
You have got a servant; you may use him kindly,
And he may honour ye:
Good morrow sister.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Good morrow to your Grace. How the wench blushes?
How like an Angel now she looks?

sp.speaker: 1. Wom.
sp.l: At first jump
Jump into the Dukes arms? we must look to you,
Indeed we must, the next jump we are journeymen.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I see the ruin of our hopes already,
Would she were at home again, milking her fathers cows

sp.speaker: 1 Wo.
sp.l: I fear she will milk all the great Courtiers first.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: This has not made ye proud?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: No certain, Madam.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: It was the Duke that kissed ye.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: It was your brother,
And therefore nothing can be meant but honour.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: But say he love ye?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: That he may with safety:
A Princes love extends to all his subjects.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: But say in more particular?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Pray fear not:
For vertues sake deliver me from doubts, Lady:
It is not the name of King, nor all his promises,
His glories, and his greatness stuck about me,
Can make me prove a Traitor to your service:
You are my Mistress, and my noble Master,
Your vertues my ambition, and your favour
The end of all my love, and all my fortune:
And when I fail in that faith --

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I believe thee,
Come wipe your eyes; I do: take you example --

sp.speaker: Pets.
sp.l: I would her eyes were out.

sp.speaker: 1 Wom.
sp.l: If the wind stand in this door,
We shall have but cold custom: some trick or other,
And speedily.

sp.speaker: Petes.
sp.l: Let me alone to think on it,

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Come, be you near me still.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: With all my duty.

div2.stage: Enter Archas, Theodor, Putskie, Ancient, and Souldiers, carrying his armour peece-meale, his Colours wound up, and his Drums in Cases.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: This is the heaviest march we ever trod Captain,

sp.speaker: Puts.
sp.l: This was not wont to be: these honoured pieces
The fiery god of war himself would smile at,
Buckled upon that body, were not wont thus,
Like Relics to be offered to long rust,
And heavy-eyed oblivion brood upon them

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: There set them down: and glorious war farewell;
Thou child of honour and ambitious thoughts,
Begot in blood, and nursed with Kingdoms ruins;
Thou golden danger, courted by thy followers
Through fires and famines, for one title from thee,
Prodigal mankind spending all his fortunes;
A long farewell I give thee: Noble Arms,
You ribs for mighty minds, you Iron houses,
Made to defy the thunder-claps of Fortune,
Rust and consuming time must now dwell with ye:
And thou good Sword that knewest the way to conquest,
Upon whose fatal edge despair and death dwelt,
That when I shook thee thus, foreshowed destruction,
Sleep now from blood, and grace my Monument:
Farewell my Eagle; when thou flewest, whole Armies
Have stooped below thee: At Passage I have seen thee,
Ruffle the Tartars, as they fled thy fury;
And bang them up together, as a Tassel,
Upon the stretch, a flock of fearful Pigeons.
I yet remember when the Volga curled,
The aged Volga, when he heaved his head up,
And raised his waters high, to see the ruins,
The ruins our Swords made, the bloody ruins;
Then flew this Bird of honour bravely, Gentlemen;
But these must be forgotten: so must these too,
And all that tend to Arms, by me forever.
Take them you holy men; my Vow take with them,
Never to wear them more: Trophies I give them,
And sacred Rites of war to adorn the Temple:
There let them hang, to tell the world their master
Is now Devotions soldier, fit for prayer,
Why do ye hang your heads? why look you sad friends?
I am not dying yet.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Ye are indeed to us sir.

sp.speaker: Puts.
sp.l: Dead to our fortunes, General.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: You will find a better,
A greater, and a stronger man to lead ye,
And to a stronger fortune: I am old friends,
Time, and the wars together make me stoop, gentlemen,
Stoop to my grave: my mind unfurnished too,
Empty and weak as I am: my poor body,
Able for nothing now but contemplation,
And that will be a task too to a Soldier:
Yet had they but encouraged me, or thought well
Of what I have done, I think I should have ventured
For one knock more, I should have made a shift yet
To have broke one staff more handsomely, and have died
Like a good fellow, and an honest soldier,
In the head of ye all, with my sword in my hand,
And so have made an end of all with credit.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Well, there will come an hour, when all these injuries
These secure slights --

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ha! no more of that sirrah,
Not one word more of that I charge ye.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: I must speak sir.
And may that tongue forget to sound your service,
That is dumb to your abuses.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Understand fool,
That voluntary I sit down.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: You are forced sir,
Forced for your safety: I too well remember
The time and cause, and I may live to curse them,
You made this vow, and whose un-nobleness,
Indeed forgetfulness of good --

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No more,
As thou art mine no more.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Whose doubts and envies --
But the devil will have his due.

sp.speaker: Puts.
sp.l: Good gentle Colonel.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: And though disgraces, and contempt of honour
Reign now, the wheel must turn again.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Peace sirrah,
Your tongue is too saucy: do ye stare upon me?
Down with that heart, down suddenly, down with it,
Down with that disobedience; tie that tongue up.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Tongue?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Do not provoke me to forget my vow, sirrah,
And draw that fatal sword again in anger.

sp.speaker: Puts.
sp.l: For heavens sake, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Do not let me doubt
Whose Son thou art, because thou canst not suffer:
Do not play with mine anger; if thou dost,
By all the loyalty my heart holds --

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: I have done sir,
Pray pardon me.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I pray ye be worthy of it:
Beshrew your heart, you have vexed me.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am sorry sir.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Go to, no more of this: be true and honest,
I know ye are man enough, mold it to just ends,
And let not my disgraces; then I am miserable,
When I have nothing left me but thy angers.

div2.stage: Flourish. Enter Duke, Burris, Boroskie, Attend. & Gent.

sp.speaker: Puts.
sp.l: If it please ye sir, the Duke.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Now, what is all this?
The meaning of this ceremonious Emblem?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Your Grace should first remember --

sp.speaker: Boros.
sp.l: There is his nature.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: I do, and shall remember still that injury,
That at the Muster, where it pleased your greatness
To laugh at my poor soldiership, to scorn it;
And more to make me seem ridiculous,
Took from my hands my charge.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: O think not so Sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And in my Fathers sight.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Heaven be my witness
I did no more, (and that with modesty,
With love and faith to you) than was my warrant,
And from your Father sealed: nor durst that rudeness
And impudence of scorn fall from my behaviour,
I ever yet knew duty.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: We shall teach ye:
I well remember too, upon some words I told ye,
Then at that time, some angry words ye answered,
If ever I were Duke, you were no soldier.
You have kept your word, and so it shall be to you.
From henceforth I dismiss ye; take your ease sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I humbly thank your Grace; this wasted body,
Beaten and bruised with Arms, dried up with troubles,
Is good for nothing else but quiet, now sir,
And holy prayers; in which, when I forget
To thank high heaven for all your bounteous favours,
May that be deaf, and my Petitions perish.

sp.speaker: Boros.
sp.l: What a smooth humble cloak he has cased his pride in?
And how he has pulled his claws in? there is no trusting --

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Speak for the best.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Believe I shall do ever.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: To make ye understand we feele not yet
Such dearth of valour, and experience,
Such a declining age of doing spirits,
That all should be confined within your Excellence,
And you, or none be honoured, take Boroskie
The place he has commanded, lead the Soldier;
A little time will bring thee to his honour,
Which has been nothing, but the worlds opinion,
The soldiers fondness, and a little fortune,
Which I believe his sword had the least share in.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: O that I durst but answer now.

sp.speaker: Puts.
sp.l: Good Colonel.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: My heart will break else: Royal sir, I know not
What you esteem men's lives, whose hourly labours,
And loss of blood, consumptions in your service,
Whose bodies are acquainted with more miseries,
And all to keep you safe, than Dogs or slaves are.
His sword the least share gained?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You will not fight with me?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: No Sir, I dare not,
You are my Prince: but I dare speak to ye,
And dare speak truth, which none of their ambitions,
That be informers to you dare once think of;
Yet truth will now but anger ye: I am sorry for it.
And so I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Even when you please Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Sirrah, see me no more.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And so may you too:
You have a house in the Country, keep you there Sir,
And when you have ruled yourself, teach your son manners.
For this time I forgive him.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Heaven forgive all:
And to your Grace a happy and long rule here.
And you Lord General, may your fights be prosperous.
In all your course, may Fame and Fortune Court you.
Fight for your Country, and your Princes safety;
Boldly, and bravely face your enemy,
And when you strike, strike with that killing virtue,
As if a general plague had seized before ye;
Danger, and doubt, and labour cast behind ye,
And then come home an old and noble story.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: A little comfort sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: As little as may be:
Farewell, you know your limit.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Alas, brave gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I do, and will observe it suddenly:
My grave; Aye, that is my limit: it is no new thing,
Nor that can make me start, or tremble at it,
To buckle with that old grim soldier now:
I have seen him in his sourest shapes and dreadfullest;
Aye, and I thank my honesty, have stood him:
That audit is cast: Farewell my honest soldiers,
Give me your hands: Farewell, fare-well good Ancient,
A stout man, and a true, thou art come in sorrow.
Blessings upon your swords, may they never fail ye.
You do but change a man: your fortune is constant;
That by your ancient valours is tied fast still:
Be valiant still and good; and when ye fight next,
When flame and fury make but one face of horror,
When the great rest of all your honour is up,
When you would think a spell to shake the enemy,
Remember me: my prayers shall be with ye.
So once again farewell.

sp.speaker: Puts.
sp.l: Let us wait upon ye.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No, no, it must not be: I have now left me
A single fortune to myself, no more,
Which needs no train, nor complement: good Captain,
You are an honest and a sober gentleman,
And one I think has loved me.

sp.speaker: Puts.
sp.l: I am sure of it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Look to my boy he is grown too head-strong for me,
And if they think him fit to carry Arms still,
His life is theirs: I have a house in the Country,
And when your better hours will give ye liberty
See me: you shall be welcome. Fortune to ye.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: I will cry no more, that will do him no good,
And it will but make me dry, and I have no money:
I will fight no more, and that will do them harm;
And if I can do that I care not for money:
I could have cursed reasonable well, and I have had the luck too
To have them hit sometimes: Whosoever thou art,
That like a devil didst possess the Duke
With these malicious thoughts; mark what I say to thee,
A plague upon thee, that is but the Preamble.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: O take the pox too:

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: They will cure one another:
I must have none but kills, and those kill stinking:
Or look ye, let the single pox possess them,
Or pox upon pox.

sp.speaker: Puts.
sp.l: That is but ill in the Arms sir,

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: It is worse in the legs, I would not with it else:
And may those grow to scabs as big as Mole hills,
And twice a day, the devil with a Currie-comb
Scratch them, and scrub them. I warrant him he has them.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: May he be ever lousy.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: That is a pleasure,
The Beggars Lechery: sometime the Soldiers:
May he be ever lazy, stink where he stands,
And Maggots breed in his brains.

sp.speaker: 2 Soul.
sp.l: Aye marry sir,
May he fall mad in love with his Grand-mother,
And kissing her, may her teeth drop into his mouth,
And one fall cross his throat, then let him gargle.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Now, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Where is the Duke pray gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Keep on your way, you cannot miss.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: I thank ye.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: If he be married, may he dream he is Cuckolded,
And when he wakes, believe, and swear he saw it:
Sue a divorce, and after find her honest:
Then in a pleasant Pigsty with his own garters,
And a fine running knot, ride to the devil.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: If these would do --

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I will never trust my mind more,
If all these fail.

sp.speaker: 1 Sould.
sp.l: What shall we do now Captain?
For by this honest hand I will be torn a-pieces,
Unless my old General go, or some that love him,
And love us equal too, before I fight more:
I can make a shoe yet, and draw it on too,
If I like the leg well.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Fight? it is likely.
No, there Will be the sport boys, when there is need of us.
They think the other Crown will do, will carry us,
And the brave golden coat of Captain Cankro
Boroskie: What a noise his very name carries?
It is gun enough to fright a nation,
He need no soldiers: if he do, for my part,
I promise ye, he is like to seek them: so I think you think too,
And all the Army: No honest brave old Archas,
We cannot so soon leave thy memory,
So soon forget thy goodness: he that does,
The scandal, and the scum of Arms be counted.

sp.speaker: Pu.
sp.l: You much rejoice me now you have hit my meaning:
I durst not press ye, till I found your spirits.
Continue thus.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: I will go and tell the Duke of it.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: No, no, he will find it soon enough, and fear it,
When once occasion comes: Another Packet.
From whence friend come ye?

sp.speaker: 2 Post.
sp.l: From the borders sir.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: What news sir, I beseech ye?

sp.speaker: 2 Post.
sp.l: Fire and sword gentlemen;
The Tartar is up, and with a mighty force,
Comes forward like a tempest, all before him
Burning and killing.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Brave boys; brave news boys.

sp.speaker: 2 Post.
sp.l: Either we must have present help --

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Still braver.

sp.speaker: 2 Post.
sp.l: Where lies the Duke?

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: He is there.

sp.speaker: 2 Post.
sp.l: Save ye gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: We are safe enough, I warrant thee:
Now the time is come.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Aye now it is come indeed, and now stand firm boys,
And let them burn on merrily.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: This City would make a marvellous fine bone-fire:
It is old dry timber, and such wood has no fellow.

sp.speaker: 2 Sold.
sp.l: Here will be trim piping anon and whining,
Like so many Pigs in a storm,
When they hear the news once,

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Here is one has heard it already,
Room for the General.

sp.speaker: Boros.
sp.l: Say I am fallen exceeding sick on the sudden,
And am not like to live.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: If ye go on Sir,
For they will kill ye certainly: they look for ye.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: I see your Lordships bound, take a suppository,
It is I Sir; a poor cast Flag of yours. The foolish Tartars
They burn and kill, if it like your honour, kill us,
Kill with Guns, with Guns my Lord, with Guns Sir.
What says your Lordship to a chick in sorrel sops?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Go, go thy ways old true-penny;
Thou hast but one fault, Thou art even too valiant.
Come to the Army gentlemen, and let us make them acquainted.

sp.speaker: Sold.
sp.l: Away, we are for ye.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why whither run ye fools, will ye leave my Lady?

sp.speaker: Petes.
sp.l: The Tartar comes, the Tartar comes.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Why let him,
I had thought you had feared no men: upon my conscience
You have tried their strengths already: stay for shame.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Shift for thyself Alinda.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Beauty bless ye:
Into what Grooms Feather-bed will ye creep now?
And there mistake the enemy: sweet youths ye are,
And of a constant courage: are you afraid of foining?

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: O my good wench, what shall become of us?
The Posts come hourly in, and bring new danger;
The Enemy is past the Volga, and bears hither
With all the blood and cruelty he carries,
My brother now will find his fault.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I doubt me.
Somewhat too late Madam: but pray fear not,
All will be well I hope. Sweet Madam shake not.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: How camest thou by this spirit? our Sex tremble.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I am not unacquainted with these dangers:
And you shall know my truth; for ere you perish,
A hundred swords shall pass through me: it is but dying,
And Madam we must do it: the manner is all:
You have a Princely Birth, take Princely thoughts to ye,
And take my counsel too; go presently,
With all the haste ye have, (I will attend ye)
With all the possible speed, to old Lord Archas,
He honours ye: with all your art persuade him,
(It will; be a dismal time else) woo him hither,
But hither Madam; make him see the danger;
For your new General looks like an Ass;
There is nothing in his face but loss.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: I will do it,
And thank thee sweet Alinda: O my Jewel,
How much I am bound to love thee: by this hand wench
If thou wert a man --

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I would I were to fight for ye.
But haste dear Madam.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: I need no spurs Alinda.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: The Lord General sick now? is this a time
For men to creep into their beds? what is become Post
Of my Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Beaten, if it please your Grace.
And all his forces sparkled.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: That is but cold news.
How now, what good news? are the soldiers ready?

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.l: Yes sir, but fight they will not, nor stir from that place
They stand in now, unless they have Lord Archas
To lead them out: they rail upon this General,
And sing songs of him, scurvy songs, to worse tunes:
And much they spare not you sir: here they swear
They will stand and see the City burnt, and dance about it,
Unless Lord Archas come before they fight for it.
It must be so sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I could wish it so too:
And to that end I have sent Lord Burris to him;
But all I fear will fail; we must die gentlemen,
And one stroke we will have for it.
What bringest thou Burris?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: That I am loath to tell: he will not come sir.
I found him at his prayers: there he tells me,
The enemy shall take him, fit for heaven:
I urged to him all our dangers, his own worths,
The Countries ruin: nay, I kneeled and prayed him;
He shook his head, let fall a tear, and pointed
Thus with his finger to the ground; a grave
I think he meant; and this was all he answered.
Your Grace was much to blame.
Where is the new General?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: He is sick poor man.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: He is a poor man indeed Sir:
Your Grace must needs go to the soldier.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: They have sent me word
They will not stir: they rail at me,
And all the spite they have --
sp.stage:
Shout within. Enter
Archas, Olimpia,
and Alinda.
sp.l: What shout is that there?
Is the enemy come so near?

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: I have brought him Sir;
At length I have wooed him thus far.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Happy sister;
O blessed woman!

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Use him nobly brother;
You never had more need: And gentlemen,
All the best powers ye have, to tongues turn presently,
To winning and persuading tongues: all my art,
Only to bring him hither, I have uttered;
Let it be yours to arm him: And good my Lord,
Though I exceed the limit you allowed me,
Which was the happiness to bring ye hither,
And not to urge ye farther: yet, see your Country,
Out of your own sweet spirit now behold it:
Turn round, and look upon the miseries,
Of every side the sears: o see the dangers;
We find them soonest, therefore hear me first sir.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Next hear your Prince;
You have said you loved him Archas,
And thought your life too little for his service:
Think not your vow too great now, now the time is,
And now you are brought to the test, touch right now soldier,
Now show the manly pureness of thy mettle:
Now if thou beest that valued man, that virtuo,
That great obedience teaching all, now stand it.
What I have said forget, my youth was hasty,
And what you said yourself forgive, you were angry.
If men could live without their faults, they were gods Archas.
He weeps, and holds his hands up: to him Burris.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: You have showed the Prince his faults:
And like a good Surgeon you have laid
That to them makes them smart: he feels it,
Let them not fester now sir: your own honour,
The bounty of that mind, and your allegiance,
Against which I take it, heaven gives no command sir,
Nor seals no vow, can better teach ye now
What ye have to do, than I, or this necessity:
Only this little is left: would ye do nobly,
And in the eye of honour truly triumph?
Conquer that mind first, and then men are nothing.

sp.speaker: Alin.
sp.l: Last, a poor virgin kneels: for loves sake General,
If ever you have loved; for her sake, sir,
For your own honesty, which is a virgin,
Look up, and pity us, be bold and fortunate.
You are a Knight, a good, and noble soldier,
And when your spurs were given ye, your sword buckled,
Then were you sworn for vertues cause, for beauties,
For chastity to strike: strike now, they suffer:
Now draw your sword, or else you are recreant,
Only a Knight in the heels, in the heart a Coward:
Your first vow honour made, your last but anger.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How like my virtuous wife this thing looks, speaks too?
So would she chide my dullness: fair one I thank ye:
My gracious sir, your pardon, next your hand:
Madam, your favour, and your prayers: gentlemen,
Your wishes and your loves; and pretty sweet one,
A favour for your Soldier.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Give him this wench.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Thus do I tie on victory.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: My Armour,
My horse, my sword, my tough staff, and my fortune,
And Olin now I come to shake thy glory.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Go brave and prosperous, our loves go with thee.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.l: Full of thy virtue, and our prayers attend thee.

sp.speaker: Bur. &c.
sp.l: Laden with victory, and we to honour thee.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Come home the son of honour,
And I will serve ye.

div2.stage: Enter Duke, Burris, and two Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: No news of Archas yet?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: But now, if it please ye
A Post came in, Letters he brought none with him,
But this delivered: He saw the Armies join,
The game of blood begun, and by our General,
Who never was acquainted, but with Conquest,
So bravely fought, he saw the Tartars shaken,
And there he said he left them.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Where is Boroskie?

sp.speaker: 1 Gen.
sp.l: He is up again, if it please ye.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Sir, methinks
This news should make ye lightsome, bring joy to ye,
It strikes our hearts with general comfort.
Gone? What should this mean, so suddenly?
He is well?

sp.speaker: 2. Gen.
sp.l: We see no other.
Would the rest were well too,
That put these starts into him.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I will go after him.
It will not be fit Sir: he has some secret in him
He would not be disturbed in: know you anything
Has crossed him since the General went?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Not any.
If there had been, I am sure I should have found it,
Only I have heard him oft complain for money;
Money he says he wants.
It may be that then.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: To him that has so many ways to raise it,
And those so honest, it cannot be.
He comes back,
And Lord Boroskie with him.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: There the game goes,
I fear some new thing hatching.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Come hither Burris,
Go see my Sister, and commend me to her,
And to my little Mistress give this token;
Tell her I will see her shortly.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Yes, I shall sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Wait you without: I would yet try him further.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: It will not be much amiss: has your grace heard yet
Of what he has done in the field?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: A Post but now
Came in, who saw them join, and has delivered,
The enemy gave ground before he parted.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: It is well.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Come, speak thy mind man: it is not for fighting
And noise of War I keep thee in my bosom,
Thy ends are nearer to me; from my childhood
Thou broughtest me up: and like another nature,
Made good all my necessities: speak boldly.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Sir, what I utter, will be thought but envy
Though I intend, high heaven knows, but your honour,
When vain and empty people shall proclaim me --
Good sir excuse me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Do you fear me for your enemy?
Speak on your duty.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Then I must, and dare sir.
When he comes home, take heed the Court receive him not,
Take heed he meet not with their loves, and praises,
That glass will show him ten times greater Sir,
And make him strive to make good that proportion,
Than ever his fortune bred him, he is honourable,
At least I strive to understand him so,
And of a nature, if not this way poisoned,
Perfect enough, easy, and sweet, but those are soon seduced sir;
He is a great man, and what that pill may work,
Prepared by general voices of the people,
Is the end of all my counsel: only this sir,
Let him retire a while, there is more hangs by it
Than you know yet: there if he stand a while well,
But till the Soldier cool, who, for their service
You must pay now most liberally, most freely,
And showered yourself into them; it is the bounty
They follow with their loves, and not the bravery.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: But where is the money? how now?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.l: Sir the Colonel,
Son to the Lord Archas, with most happy news
Of the Tartars overthrow, without here
Attends your graces pleasure.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Be not seen sir,
He is a bold fellow, let me stand his thunders,
To the Court he must not come: no blessing here sir,
No face of favour, if you love your honour.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Do what you think is meetest; I will retire sir.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Conduct him in sir -- welcome noble Colonel,

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: That is much from your Lordship: pray where is the Duke?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: We hear you have beat the Tartar.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Is he busy sir?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Have ye taken Olin yet?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I would fain speak with him,

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: How many men have ye lost?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Does he lie this way?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I am sure you fought it bravely.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I must see him.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You cannot yet, ye must not, what is your Commission?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: No gentleman of the Chamber here?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Why pray ye sir?
Am not I fit to entertain your business?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I think you are not sir; I am sure ye shall not.
I bring no tales, nor flatteries: In my tongue sir,
I carry no forked stings.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You keep your bluntness.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You are deceived: it keeps me: I had felt else
Some of your plagues ere this: but good sir trifle not,
I have business to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: He is not well sir,
And cannot now be spoke withal.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Not well sir?
How would he have beem, if we had lost? not well sir?
I bring him news to make him well: his enemy
That would have burnt his City here, and your house too,
Your brave gilt house, my Lord, your honours hangings,
Where all your Ancestors, and all their battles,
Their silk and golden battles are deciphered:
That would not only have abused your buildings,
Your goodly buildings sir, and have drunk dry your butteries,
Purloined your Lordships plate, the Duke bestowed on you,
For turning handsomely on the toe, and trimmed your Virgins,
Trimmed them of a new cut, if it like your Lordship,
It is ten to one, your wife too, and the curse is
You had had no remedy against these Rascals,
No Law, if it like your honour; would have killed you too
And roasted ye, and eaten ye, ere this time:
Notable knaves my Lord, unruly Rascals:
These youths have we tide up, put muzzles on them,
And paired their nails, that honest civil Gentlemen,
And such most noble persons as yourself is,
May live in peace, and rule the land with a twine thread.
These news I bring,

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: And were they thus delivered ye?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: My Lord, I am no pen-man, nor no Orator,
My tongue was never oiled with Here if it like ye,
There I beseech ye, weigh, I am a soldier,
And truth I covet only, no fine terms sir;
I come not to stand treating here; my business
Is with the Duke, and of such general blessing --

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You have overthrown the enemy, we know it,
And we rejoice in it; ye have done like honest subjects,
You have done handsomely and well.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: But well sir?
But handsomely and well? what are we jugglers?
I will do all that in cutting up a Capon.
But handsomely and well? does your Lordship take us
For the Dukes Tumblers? we have done bravely sir,
Ventured our lives like men.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Then bravely be it.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: And for as brave rewards we look, and graces,
We have sweat and bled for it sir.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: And ye may have it,
If you will stay the giving. Men that thank themselves first,
For any good they do, take off the lustre,
And blot the benefit.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Are these the welcomes,
The Bells that ring out our rewards? pray heartily,
Early and late, there may be no more enemies:
Do my good Lord, pray seriously, and sigh too,
For if there be --

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: They must be met, and fought with.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: By whom? by you? they must be met and flatterered.
Why, what a devil ailed ye to do these things?
With what assurance dare ye mock men thus?
You have but single lives, and those I take it
A Sword may find too: why do ye dam the Duke up?
And choake that course of love that like a River
Should fill our empty veins again with comforts?
But if ye use these knick knacks,
This fast and loose, with faithful men and honest,
You will be the first will find it.

div2.stage: Enter Archas, Souldiers, Putskey, Ancient, and others,

sp.speaker: Boros.
sp.l: You are too untemperate.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Better be so, and thief too, than unthankful:
Pray use this old man so, and then we are paid all.
The Duke thanks ye for your service, and the Court thanks ye,
And wonderful desirous they are to see ye;
Pray heaven we have room enough to march for May-games,
Pageants, and bonfires for your welcome home Sir;
Here your most noble friend the Lord Boroskey,
A Gentleman too tender of your credit,
And ever in the Dukes ear, for your good Sir,
Crazy and sickly, yet to be your servant,
Has leapt into the open air to meet ye.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: The best is your words wound not, you are welcome home Sir.
Heartily welcome home, and for your service,
The noble overthrow you gave the Enemy,
The Duke salutes ye too with all his thanks Sir.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Sure they will now regard us.

sp.speaker: Puts.
sp.l: There is a reason:
But by the changing of the Colonels countenance,
The rolling of his eyes like angry billows;
I fear the wind is not down yet, Ancient.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Is the Duke well Sir?

sp.speaker: Boros.
sp.l: Not much unhealthy,
Only a little grudging of an ague,
Which cannot last: he has heard, which makes him fearful,
And loath as yet to give your worth due welcome,
The sickness hath been somewhat hot in the Army,
Which happily may prove more doubt, than danger,
And more his fear than fate: yet howsoever,
An honest care --

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ye say right, and it shall be;
For though upon my life it is but a rumour,
A mere opinion, without faith or fear in it;
For Sir, I thank heaven, we never stood more healthy,
Never more high and lusty; yet to satisfy,
We cannot be too curious or too careful
Of what concerns his state, we will draw away Sir,
And lodge at further distance, and less danger.

sp.speaker: Boros.
sp.l: It will be well.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: It will be very scurvy.
I smell it out, it stinks abominably,
Stir it no more.

sp.speaker: Boros.
sp.l: The Duke Sir would have you too,
For a short day or two, retire to your own house,
Whither himself will come to visit ye,
And give ye thanks.

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: I shall attend his pleasure.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: A trick, a lousy trick: so ho, a trick boys.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How now, what is that?

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: I thought I had found a Hare Sir,
But it is a Fox, an old Fox, shall we hunt him?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No more such words.

sp.speaker: Boros.
sp.l: The soldier is grown too saucy,
You must tie him straighter up.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I do my best Sir;
But men of free-born minds sometimes will sly out.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: May not we see the Duke?

sp.speaker: Boros.
sp.l: Not at this time Gentlemen,
Your General knows the cause.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: We have no plague Sir,
Unless it be in our pay, nor no pox neither;
Or if we had, I hope that good old Courtier
Will not deny us place there.

sp.speaker: Puts.
sp.l: Certain my Lord,
Considering what we are and what we have done;
If not, what need ye may have, it would be better,
A great deal nobler, and taste honester
To use us with more sweetness; men that dig
And lash away their lives at the Carts tail,
Double our comforts; meat, and their Masters thanks too,
When they work well, they have; Men of our quality,
When they do well, and venture for it with valour,
Fight hard, lie hard, feed hard, when they come home Sir,
And know these are deserving things, things worthy,
Can you then blame them if their minds a little
Be stirred with glory? it is a pride becomes them,
A little seasoned with ambition,
To be respected, reckoned well, and honoured
For what they have done: when to come home thus poorly,
And met with such unjointed joy, so looked on,
As if we had done no more but dressed a horse well;
So entertained, as if I thank ye Gentlemen,
Take that to drink, had power to please a soldier?
Where be the shouts, the bells rung out, the people?
The Prince himself?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Peace: I perceive your eye Sir
Is fixed upon this Captain for his freedom,
And happily you find his tongue too forward;
As I am Master of the place, I carry,
It is fit I think so too, but were I this man,
No stronger tie upon me, than the truth
And tongue to tell it, I should speak as he does,
And think with modesty enough, such Saints
That daily thrust their loves and lives through hazards,
And fearless for their Countries peace, march hourly
Through all the doors of death, and know the darkest,
Should better be canonised for their service:
What labour would these men neglect, what danger
Where honour is, though seated in a billow,
Rising as high as heaven, would not these soldiers,
Like to so many Sea-gods charge up to it?
Do you see these swords? times Scythe was never so sharp Sir;
Nor ever at one harvest mowed such handfuls:
Thoughts never so sudden, nor belief so sure,
When they are drawn, and were it not sometimes;
I swim upon their angers to allay them,
And like a calm depress their fell intentions;
They are so deadly sure, nature would suffer --
And whose are all these glories? why, their Princes,
Their Countries, and their Friends? Alas, of all these,
And all the happy ends they bring, the blessings,
They only share the labours, a little joy then,
And outside of a welcome, at an upshot
Would not have done amiss Sir; But howsoever
Between me and my duty, no crack Sir
Shall dare appear: I hope by my example
No discontent in them: without doubt Gentlemen,
The Duke will both look suddenly and truly
On your deserts: Methinks it were good they were paid Sir.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: They shall be immediately; I stay for money;
And any favour else -- .

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: We are all bound to ye;
And so I take my leave Sir; when the Duke pleases
To make me worthy of his eyes --

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Which will be suddenly,
I know his good thoughts to ye.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: With all duty.
And all humility, I shall attend Sir.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Once more you are welcome home: these shall be satisfied.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Be sure we be: and handsomely.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Wait you on me sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And honestly: no juggling.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Will ye come sir?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Pray do not doubt.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: We are no Boys.

div2.stage: Enter a Gent. and 2 or 3 with money.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Here is money from the Duke, if it please your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: It is well.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: How sour the Soldiers look?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Is it told?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Yes: and for every company a double pay,
And the Dukes love to all.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: That is worth a ducat.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You that be Officers, see it discharged then,
Why do not ye take it up?

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: It is too heavy:
Body of me, I have strained mine arm.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Do ye scorn it?

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Has your Lordship any dice about ye? sit round Gentlemen.
And come on seven for my share.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Do you think sir,
This is the end we fight? can this dirt draw us
To such a stupid tameness, that our service
Neglected, and looked lamely on, and skewed at
With a few honourable words, and this, is righted?
Have not we eyes and ears, to hear and see Sir,
And minds to understand the slights we carry?
I come home old, and full of hurts, men look on me
As if I had got them from a whore, and shun me;
I tell my griefs, and fear my wants, I am answered,
Alas it is pity! pray dine with me on Sunday:
These are the sores we are sick of, the minds maladies.
And can this cure them? you should have used us nobly,
And for our doing well, as well proclaimed us,
To the worlds eye, have showed and fainted us,
Then ye had paid us bravely: then we had shined sir,
Not in this gilded stuff but in our glory:
You may take back your money.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: This I feared still.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Consider better Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Thank your Lordship:
And now I will put on my considering cap:
My Lord, that I am no Courtier, you may guess it
By having no suit to you for this money:
For though I want, I want not this, nor shall not,
Whilst you want that civility to rank it
With those rights we expected; money grows sir,
And men must gather it, all is not put in one purse.
And that I am no Carter, I could never whistle yet:
But that I am a Soldier, and a Gentleman,
And a fine Gentleman, if it like your honour,
And a most pleasant companion: all you that are witty,
Come list to my ditty: come set in boys,
With your Lordships patience.
How do you like my Song, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Even as I like yourself, but it would be a great deal better,
You would prove a great deal wiser, and take this money,
In your own phrase I speak now sir, and it is very well.
You have learned to sing; for since you prove so liberal,
To refuse such means as this, maintain your voice still,
It will prove your best friend.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: It is a singing age sir,
A merry moon here now: I will follow it:
Fiddling, and fooling now, gains more than fighting.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: What is it you blench at? what would you ask? speak freely.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: And so we dare: a triumph for the General.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: And then an honour special to his virtue.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: That we may be preferred that have served for it,
And crammed up into favour like the worshipful,
At least upon the Cities charge made drunk
For one whole year; we have done them ten years service;
That we may enjoy our lechery without grudging,
And mine, or thine be nothing, all things equal,
And catch as catch may be proclaimed: that when we borrow,
And have no will to pay again, no Law
Lay hold upon us, nor no Court control us.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Some of these may come to pass; the Duke may do them,
And no doubt will: the General will find too,
And so will you, if you but stay with patience: I have no power.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Nor will: come fellow Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Pray be not so distrustful.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: There are ways yet,
And honest ways; we are not brought up Statues.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: If your Lordship
Have any silk stockings, that have holes in the heels,
Or ever an honourable Cassock that wants buttons,
I could have cured such maladies: your Lordships custom
And my good Ladies, if the bones want setting
In her old bodies --

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: This is disobedience.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Eight pence a day, and hard Eggs.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Troop off Gentlemen,
Some Coin we have, whilst this lasts, or our credits,
We will never sell our General's worth for six-pence.
Ye are beholding to us.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Fare ye well Sir,
And buy a pipe with that: do ye see this scarf sir?
By this hand I will cry Brooms in it, birchen Brooms sir,
Before I eat one bit from your benevolence.
Now to our old occupations again.
By your leave Lord.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You will bite when ye are sharper; take up the money.
This love I must remove, this fondness to him,
This tenderness of heart; I have lost my way else.
There is no sending man, they will not take it,
They are yet too full of pillage,
They will dance for it ere it be long:
Come, bring it after.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How now, refused their money?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Very bravely,
And stand upon such terms it is terrible.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Where is Archas?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: He is retired Sir, to his house,
According to your pleasure, full of duty
To outward show: but what within --

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Refuse it?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Most confidently: it is not your revenues
Can feed them sir, and yet they have found a General
That knows no ebb of bounty: there they eat Sir,
And loath your invitations.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: It is not possible,
He is poor as they.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You will find it otherwise.
Pray make your journey thither presently,
And as ye go I will open ye a wonder.
Good sir this morning.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Follow me, I will do it.

div2.stage: Enter Olimpia, Alinda, Burris, and Gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: But do you think my brother loves her.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Certain Madam,
He speaks much of her, and sometimes with wonder,
Oft wishes she were nobler born.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Do you think him honest?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Your Grace is nearer to his heart, than I am,
Upon my life I hold him so.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: It is a poor wench,
I would not have her wronged: methinks my Brother --
But I must not give rules to his affections;
Yet if he weigh her worth --

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: You need not fear Madam.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: I hope I shall not: Lord Burris
I love her well; I know not, there is something
Makes me bestow more than a care upon her:
I do not like that ring, from him to her;
I mean to women of her way, such tokens
Rather appear as baits, than royal bounties:
I would not have it so.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: You will not find it,
Upon my troth I think his most ambition
Is but to let the world know he has a handsome Mistress:
Will your Grace command me any service to him?

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Remember all my duty.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Blessings crown ye:
What is your will Lady?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Anything that is honest;
And if you think it fits so poor a service,
Clad in a ragged virtue, may reach him,
I do beseech your Lordship speak it humbly.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Fair one I will: in the best phrase I have too,
And so I kiss your hand

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Your Lordships servant.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Come hither wench, what art thou doing with that Ring.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I am looking on the posy, Madam.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: The Jewels set within.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: But where the joy wench,
When that invisible Jewel is lost? why dost thou smile so?
What unhappy meaning hast thou?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Nothing Madam,
But only thinking what strange spells these Rings have,
And how they work with some.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: I fear with you too.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: This could not cost above a Crown.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: It will cost you
The shaving of your crown, if not the washing.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: But he that sent it, makes the virtue greater.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Aye and the vice too Madam: goodness bless me:
How fit it is for my finger.

sp.speaker: 2 W.
sp.l: No doubt you will find too
A finger fit for you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Sirrah, Petesca,
What wilt thou give me for the good that follows this?
But thou hast Rings enough, thou art provided:
Heigh ho, what must I do now?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: You will be taught that,
The easiest part that ever you learn it, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Aye me, aye me.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: You will divide too, shortly.
Your voice comes finely forward.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Come hither wanton,
Thou art not surely as thou sayst.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: I would not:
But sure there is a witchcraft in this Ring, Lady.
Lord how my heart leaps.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: It will go pit a pat shortly.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: And now methinks a thousand of the Dukes shapes.

sp.speaker: 2 W.
sp.l: Will no less serve ye?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: In ten thousand smiles.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Heaven bless the wench.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: With eyes that will not be denied to enter;
And such soft sweet embraces; take it from me,
I am undone else Madam: I am lost else.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: What ails the girl?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How suddenly I am altered?
And grown myself again? do not you feele it?

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: Wear that, and I will wear this:
I will try the strength of it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: How cold my blood grows now?
Here is sacred virtue:
When I leave to honour this,
Every hour to pay a kiss,
When each morning I arise,
Or I forget a sacrifice:
When this figure in my faith,
And the pureness that it hath,
I pursue not with my will,
Nearer to arrive at still:
When I lose, or change this Jewel,
Fly me faith, and heaven be cruel.

sp.speaker: Olim.
sp.l: You have half confirmed me,
Keep but that way sure,
And what this charm can do, let me endure.

div2.stage: Enter Archas, Theodore, 2 Doughters. Honora and Viola.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Carry yourself discreetly, it concerns me,
The Duke is come in, none of your froward passions,
Nor no distastes to any: Prithee Theodor,
By my life, boy, it will ruin me.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I have done Sir,
so there be no foul play he brings along with him.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What is that to you?
Let him bring what please him,
And whom, and how.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: So they mean well --

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Is it fit you be a Judge sirrah,

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: It is fit I feele Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Get a banquet ready,
And trim yourselves up handsomely.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: To what end?
Do you mean to make them whores?
Hang up a sign then,
And set them out to Livery.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Whose son art thou?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Yours Sir, I hope: but not of your disgraces.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Full twenty thousand men I have commanded,
And all their minds with this, calmed all their angers;
And shall a boy of mine own breed too, of mine own blood,
One crooked stick --

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Pray take your way, and thrive in it,
I will quit your house, if taint or black dishonour
Light on ye, it is your own, I have no share in it.
Yet if it do fall out so, as I fear it,
And partly find it too --

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Hast thou no reverence?
No duty in thee?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: This shall show I obey ye!
I dare not stay: I would have showed my love too,
And that you ask as duty, with my life sir,
Had you but thought me worthy of your hazards,
Which heaven preserve ye from, and keep the Duke too:
And there is an end of my wishes, God be with ye.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Stubborn, yet full of that we all love, honesty,
Lord Burris, where is the Duke?

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: In the great chamber Sir,
And there stays till he see you, ye have a fine house here.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: A poor contented lodge, unfit for his presence,
Yet all the joy it hath.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I hope a great one, and for your good, brave Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I thank ye Lord:
And now my service to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: I will wait on ye.

div2.stage: Enter Duke, Boroskey, Gent. and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: May this be credited?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Disgrace me else,
And never more with favour look upon me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: It seems impossible.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: It cannot choose Sir,
Till your own eyes behold it; but that it is so,
And that by this means the too haughty soldier
Has been so crammed and fed, he cares not for ye;
Believe, or let me perish: Let your eyes
As you observe the house, but where I point it,
Make stay, and take a view, and then you have found it.

div2.stage: Enter Archas, Burris, 2 Daughters and Servant.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I will follow your direction: welcome Archas,
You are welcome home brave Lord, we are come to visit ye,
And thank ye for your service.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: It was so poor Sir,
In true respect of what I owe your Highness,
It merits nothing.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Are these fair ones yours Lord?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Their Mother made me think so Sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Stand up Ladies:
Beshrew my heart they are fair ones; methinks fitter
The lustre of the Court, than thus live darkened:
I would see your house Lord Archas, it appears to me,
A handsome pile.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: It is neat but no great structure;
I will be your Graces guide, give me the keys there.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Lead on, we will follow ye: begin with the Gallery,
I think that is one.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: It is so, if it please ye Sir,
The rest above are lodgings all.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Go on Sir.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: The Duke gone thither, do you say?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Yes marry do I,
And all the ducklings too: but what they will do there. --

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: I hope they will crown his service.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: With a Custard;
This is no weather for rewards; they crown his service?
Rather, they go to shave his crown: I was rated,
As if I had been a dog had worried sheep, out of doors,
For making but a doubt.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: They must now grace him.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Mark but the end.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: I am sure they should reward him, they cannot want him

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: They that want honesty, want anything.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: The Duke is so noble in his own thoughts.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: That I grant ye,
If those might only sway him: but it is most certain,
So many new born slies, his light gave life to,
Buzz in his beams, flesh flies, and Butterflies,
Hornets, and humming Scarabs, that not one honey Bee
That is laden with true labour, and brings home
Increase, and credit, can scape rifling,
And what she sucks for sweet, they turn to bitterness.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Shall we go see what they do and talk our minds to them?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: That we have done too much, and to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Shall we be hanged for him?
I have a great mind to be hanged now
For doing some brave thing for him; a worse end will take me
And for an action of no worth; not honour him?
Upon my conscience even the devil, the very devil
(Not to belie him) thinks him an honest man,
I am sure he has sent him souls any times these twenty years,
Able to furnish all his fishmarket.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Leave thy talking
And come, let us go to dinner and drink to him,
We shall hear more ere supper time: if he be honoured,
He has deserved it well, and we shall fight for it:
If he be ruined so, we know the worst then,
And for myself I will meet it.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: I never fear it.

div2.stage: Enter Duke, Archas, Borosky, Burris, Gentlemen, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: They are handsome rooms all, well contrived and fitted,
Full of convenience, the prospects excellent.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Now will your Grace pass down, and do me but the honour
To taste a Country banquet?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What room is that?
I would see all now; what conveyance has it?
I see you have kept the best part yet; pray open it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Ha? I misdoubted this: it is of no receipt sir,
For your eyes most unfit --

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I long to see it,
Because I would judge of the whole piece: some excellent paintings,
Or some rare spoils you would keep to entertain me
Another time, I know.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: In troth there is not,
Nor anything worth your sight: below I have
Some fountains, and some ponds.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I would see this now.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Borosky, thou art a knave; It contains nothing
But rubbish from the other rooms and unnecessaries:
Will it please you see a strange Clock?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: This, or nothing:
Why should you bar it up thus with defences
Above the rest, unless it contained something
More excellent, and curious of keeping:
Open it, for I will see it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: The keys are lost sir;
Does your grace think if it were fit for you,
I could be so unmannerly?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I will see it, and either show it --

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Good sir --

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thank ye Archas,
You show your love abundantly,
Do I use to entreat thus? force it open,

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: That were inhospitable: you are his guest sir,
And with his greatest joy, to entertain ye.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Hold thy peace fool; will ye open it?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Sir, I cannot.
I must not if I could.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Go break it open.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I must withstand that force: Be not too rash Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Unarm him first, then if he be not obstinate,
Preserve his life.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I thank your grace, I take it:
And now take you the keys, go in and see Sir;
There feed your eyes with wonder, and thank that traitor,
That thing that sells his faith for favour.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.l: Sir, what moves ye?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I have kept mine pure: Lord Burris there is a Judas,
That for a smile will sell ye all: a Gentleman?
The Devil has more truth, and has maintained it;
A whores heart more belief in it.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What is all this Archas?
I cannot blame ye to conceal it so,
This most inestimable treasure.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yours Sir.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Nor do I wonder now the soldier sleights me.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Be not deceived; he has had no favour here Sir,
Nor had you known this now, but for that pickthank,
That lost man in his faith, he has revealed it,
To suck a little honey from ye has betrayed it.
I swear he smiles upon me, and forsworn too,
Thou cracked, uncurrent Lord: I will tell ye all Sir:
Your Sire, before his death, knowing your temper,
To be as bounteous as the air, and open,
As flowing as the Sea to all that followed ye,
Your great mind fit for war and glory, thriftily
Like a great husband, to preserve your actions,
Collected all this treasure: to our trusts,
To mine I mean, and to that long tongued Lords there,
He gave the knowledge, and the charge of all this,
Upon his death-bed too: And on the Sacrament
He swore us thus, never to let this treasure
Part from our secret keepings, till no hope
Of subject could relieve ye, all your own wasted,
No help of those that loved ye could supply ye,
And then some great exploit afoot; my honesty
I would have kept till I had made this useful;
I showed it, and I stood it to the tempest,
And useful to the end it was left: I am cozened,
And so are you too, if you spend this vainly;
This worm that crept into ye has abused ye,
Abused your fathers care, abused his faith too:
Nor can this mass of money make him man more,
A fleaed dog has more soul, an Ape more honesty:
All mine ye have amongst it, farewell that,
I cannot part with it nobler; my heart is clear,
My conscience smooth as that, no rub upon it,
But O thy hell.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I seek no heaven from you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Thy gnawing hell Boroskey, it will find thee:
Would ye heap coals upon his head has wronged ye,
Has ruined your estate? give him this money,
Melt it into his mouth.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What little Trunk is that,
That there on the top, that is locked?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You will find it rich Sir,
Richer I think than all.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You were not covetous,
Nor wont to weave your thoughts with such a coarseness;
Pray rack not honesty.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Be sure ye see it.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Bring out the Trunk.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: You will find that treasure too,
All I have left me now.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: What is this a poor gown?
And this a piece of Seneca?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yes sure Sir,
More worth than all your gold, yet ye have enough of it,
And of a Mine far purer, and more precious:
This sells no friends, nor searches into counsels,
And yet all counsel and all friends live here Sir,
Betrays no faith, yet handles all that is trusty;
Will it please ye leave me this.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: With all my heart Sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What says your Lordship to it?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I dare not rob ye.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Poor miserable men, you have robbed yourselves both;
This gown, and this unvalued treasure, your brave Father,
Found me a child at school with, in his progress,
Where such a love he took to some few answers,
Unhappy boyish toys hit in my head then,
That suddenly I made him thus as I was;
For here was all the wealth I brought his Highness:
He carried me to Court, there bred me up.
Bestowed his favours on me, taught me Arms first,
With those an honest mind; I served him truly,
And where he gave me trust, I think I failed not;
Let the world speak: I humbly thank your Highness,
You have done more, and nobler, eased mine age Sir;
And to this care, a fair quietus given:
Now to my Book again.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You have your wish Sir,
Let some bring off the treasure.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Some is his sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: None, none my Lord: a poor unworthy reaper,
The harvest is his graces.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Thank ye Archas.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: But will not you repent Lord? when this is gone,
Where will your Lordship? --

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Pray take you no care sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Does your Grace like my house?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Wondrous well Archas,
You have made me richly welcome.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I did my best sir,
Is there anything else may please your Grace?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Your daughters
I had forgot, send them to Court.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: How is that Sir?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I said your daughters; see it done: I will have them
Attend my sister, Archas.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Thank your Highness.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: And suddenly.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Through all the ways I dare,
I will serve your temper, though you try me too far.

div2.stage: Enter Theodor, Putskey, Ancient, and Servant.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I wonder we hear no news.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Here is your fathers servant,
He comes in haste too, now we shall know all sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I am glad I have met you sir; your father
Entreats ye presently make haste unto him.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What news?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: None of the best Sir, I am ashamed to tell it,
Pray ask no more.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Did not I tell ye Gentlemen?
Did not I prophecy? he is undone then.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Not so Sir, but as near it --

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: There is no help now;
The Army is scattered all, though discontent,
Not to be rallied up in haste to help this.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Plague of the devil; have ye watched your seasons?
We shall watch you ere long.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Farewell, there is no cure,
We must endure all now: I know what I will do.

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Nay there is no striving, they have a hand upon us,
A heavy, and a hard one.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Now I have it,
We have yet some Gentlemen, some boys of mettle,
(What, are we bobbed thus still, colted, and carted?)
And one mad trick We will have to shame these vipers;
Shall I bless them?

sp.speaker: Put.
sp.l: Farewell: I have thought my way too.

sp.speaker: Anc.
sp.l: Were never such rare cries in Christendom,
As Mosco shall afford: We will live by fooling,
Now fighting is gone, and they shall find and feele it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: No more: it must be so; do you think I would send ye
Your father, and your friend --

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Pray Sir be good to us,
Alas, we know no Court, nor seek that knowledge;
We are content like harmless things at home,
Children of your content, bred up in quiet,
Only to know ourselves, to seek a wisdom
From that we understand, easy, and honest;
To make our actions worthy of your honour,
Their ends as innocent as we begot them:
What shall we look for Sir, what shall we learn there,
That this more private sweetness cannot teach us?
Virtue was never built upon ambition,
Nor the souls beauties bred out of bravery:
What a terrible Father would you seem to us,
Now you have moulded us, and wrought our tempers
To easy and obedient ways, uncrooked,
Where the fair mind can never lose, nor loiter,
Now to divert our Natures, now to stem us
Roughly against the tide of all this treasure?
Would ye have us proud? it is sooner bred, than buried;
Wickedly proud? for such things dwell at Court Sir.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Would you have your children learn to forget their father,
And when he dies dance on his Monument?
Shall we seek virtue in a Satin gown,
Embroidered virtue? faith in a well-curled feather?
And set our credits to the tune of green sleeves?
This may be done; and if you like, it shall be.
You should have sent us thither, when we were younger,
Our Maiden-heads at a higher rate, our Innocence
Able to make a Mart indeed: we are now too old Sir,
Perhaps they will think too cunning too, and slight us,
Besides we are altogether unprovided,
Unfurnished utterly of the rules should guide us:
This Lord comes licks his hand; and protests to me:
Compares my beauty to a thousand fine things;
Mountains, and fountains, trees, and stars, and goblins;
Now have not I the fashion to believe him;
He offers me the honourable courtesy,
To lie with me all night, what a misery is this?
I am bred up so foolishly alas I dare not,
And how madly these things will show there.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I send ye not,
Like parts infected, to draw more corruption;
Like Spiders to grow great, with growing evil:
With your own vertues seasoned, and my prayers,
The card of goodness in your minds, that shows ye
When ye sail false; the needle touched with honour,
That through the blackest storms, still points at happiness:
Your bodies the tall barks, ribbed round with goodness;
Your heavenly souls the Pilots, thus I send you;
Thus I prepare your voyage, sound before ye,
And ever as you sail through this worlds vanity,
Discover shoals, rocks, quicksands, cry out to ye,
Like a good Master tack about for honour:
The Court is virtue's school; at least it should be;
Nearer the Sun the Mine lies, the metal is purer:
Be it granted, if the Spring be once infected.
Those branches that flow from him must run muddy;
Say you find some sins there, and those no small ones,
And they like lazy fits begin to shake ye:
Say they affect your strengths, my happy children,
Great things through greatest hazards are achieved still,
And then they shine, then goodness has his glory,
His Crown fast riveted, then time moves under,
Where, through the mist of errors, like the Sun,
Through thick and pitchy clouds, he breaks out nobly.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I thank you Sir, you have made me half a soldier,
I will to court most willingly, most fondly.
And if there be such stirring things amongst them,
Such travellers into Virginia,
As fame reports, if they can win me, take me:
I think I have a close ward, and a sure one;
A honest mind I hope, it is petticoat-proof,
Chain proof, and jewel-proof: I know it is gold proof,
A Coach and four horses cannot draw me from it:
As for your handsome faces, and filed tongues,
Curled Millers heads; I have another word for them,
And yet I will flatter too, as fast as they do,
And lie, but not as lewdly: Come, be valiant sister,
She that dares not stand the push of the Court, dares nothing,
And yet come off ungreased: Sir, like you,
We both affect great dangers now; and the world shall see
All glory lies not in man's victory.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Mine own Honora.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I am very fearful,
Would I were stronger built? you would have me honest?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Or not at all my Viola.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I will think on it,
For it is no easy promise, and live there;
Do you think we shall do well?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Why what should ail us?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Certain they will tempt us strongly: beside the glory
Which women may affect: they are handsome gentlemen,
Every part speaks: nor is it one denial,
Nor two, nor ten: from every look we give them,
They will frame a hope: even from our prayers, promises.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Let them feed so, and be fat: there is no fear wench,
If thou beest fast to thyself.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: I hope I shall be:
And your example will work more.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Thou shalt not want it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: How do you Sir, can you lend a man an Angel?
I hear you let out money.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Very well Sir,
You are pleasantly disposed: I am glad to see it,
Can you lend me your patience, and be ruled by me?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Is it come to Patience now?

sp.speaker: Arch.
sp.l: Is it not a virtue?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: I know not. I never found it so.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: That is because
Thy anger ever knows, and not thy judgment.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: I know you have been rifled.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Nothing less boy:
Lord what opinions these vain people publish?
Rifled of what?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Study your virtue patience,
It may get Mustard to your meat. Why in such haste sir,
Sent ye for me?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: For this end only, Theodore,
To wait upon your sisters to the Court;
I am commanded they live there.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: To the Court sir?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: To the Court I say.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And must I wait upon them?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yes, it is most fit ye should, ye are their brother.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Is this the business? I had thought your mind sir
Had been set forward on some noble action,
Something had truly stirred ye. To the Court with these?
Why they are your daughters sir.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: All this I know sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: The good old woman on a bed he threw.
To the Court?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Thou art not mad.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Nor drunk as you are:
Drunk with your duty sir: do you call it duty?
A pox on duty, what can these do there?
What should they do? Can ye look Babies sisters
In the young Gallants eyes, and twirl their Band-strings?
Can ye ride out to air yourselves? pray sir,
Be serious with me: do you speak this truly?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Why didst thou never hear of women
Yet at Court boy?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Yes, and good women too, very good women,
Excellent honest women: but are you sure sir,
That these will prove so?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: There is the danger brother.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: God-a-mercy wench, thou hast a grudging of it.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Now be you serious sir, and observe what I say,
Do it, and do it handsomely: go with them.
